attributes.title: The Influence of Nature of Prosociality
attributes.description: In this study we will investigate the effect of nature on prosociality. In one condition, participants will be exposed to a nature-based video, while in the other condition, participants will watch an urban-based video. We expect participants in the nature condition to show increased levels of prosociality, measured by the amount of money spontaneously allocated to others (family, friends, and/or charity). Furthermore, we will measure self-transcendence, and mood. We will test if these variables are affected by exposure to nature and if they relate to your levels of prosociality.

q2.value:
H1: Being exposed to a nature video (in comparison to an urban video) induces an experience of self-transcendence (reduced self-boundaries and self-salience, and increased connectedness with other peoples and the environment).
H2: Experiencing self-transcendence promotes prosociality.
H3: Self-Transcendence plays a mediating role in the relation between exposure to nature and prosociality. We predict that the nature experience will increase self-transcendence, which in turn will result in higher levels of prosociality.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study will follow a between-subjects design (nature vs. urban environment). Participants will be randomly assigned to either watch a video of nature or watch a video or urban scenes.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected through Prolific Academic LTD and inclusion criteria are that participants need to be over 18 years of age and be proficient in the English language.

q12.value: In order to determine the sample size for the mediation analysis, a power analysis was conducted using a Monte Carlo power analysis simulation (Schoemann, Boulton, & Short, 2017). The results showed that a minimum of 110 participants would be needed to detect a small to medium effect size at the standard significance levels within psychological research (α  = .05 and power [1−β ] = .80; Cohen, 1988). To ensure that we end up with the correct sample size for the analysis, we will recruit 20% more participants, which leads to an overall sample size of 132 participants

question.value:
Environment condition: participants will either watch a 2 min video of nature or a 2 min video of urban scenes. 
Nature video URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qHZ3rV6TzMs
Non-nature control video URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4nfG3xo3mBU

Self-Transcendence: Self-loss and Connectedness sub scale of AWE-S (Yaden, Kaufman, Hyde, Chirico, Gaggioli, Zhang, & Keltner, 2019), Self-Transcendence sub scale of Existential Fulfillment Scale (Loonstra, Brouwers, & Tomic, 2007)
Mood: PANAS; Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988
Prosociality: will be assessed with semi-open question in which participants will be asked to write down what they would do if they won 100,000 euros in a lottery game. Participants will be asked to specify the percentage of money they would allocate for each expenditure, and to briefly describe them. The percentage of money spontaneously allocated to others (family, friends, and/or charity) will be coded as a measure of prosociality.

To test the hypothesis, we will use the jAMM package for Jamovi. To establish whether the effect of contact with nature on prosociality is mediated by self-transcendence we will first estimate a simple regression with Environment (nature vs. urban scenes) as dependent variable and Prosociality as independent variable to obtain the overall effect of the independent variable on the dependent variable. We expect a significant effect of Environment.  Then, we will estimate a mediation model: the effect of Environment on Prosociality mediated by Self-Transcendence. To obtain the mediated effect coefficients we will estimate two regression: (a) Self-Transcendence as dependent and Environment as independent and (2) Prosociality as dependent and Self-Transcendence and Environment as independent. We expect a significant effect for both regressions.

attributes.title: Digital health competencies for primary healthcare professionals
attributes.description: Digital technologies have already opened wide possibilities for shaping the future of primary healthcare, by allowing people to manage their health more effectively, improving the diagnosing of diseases, and monitoring the impact of policies, just to name a few examples. However, for primary healthcare systems to be able to take full advantage of these technologies, a capable, digitally literate workforce is necessary. What is not fully understood is which digital health competencies (DHC) are necessary for primary care (PC) providers and health workers to possess in order to implement and utilize digital health in PC. This knowledge hinges on a variety of factors including the type of technologies used in PC, the type of health worker, and how technologically advanced is the context and setting of the PC in question. This scoping review aims to provide a summarized overview of the context, healthcare worker, technologies and possibly evidence regarding digital health competencies in primary care to try to identify a set of generic primary care digital health technologies that every primary care provider should have.
attributes.withdrawal_justification: I need to add "Scoping Review Protocol" to the title of this registration

question4b.value: A large sample of 24,955 first-year, full-time students in 54 bachelor programs of a major university in the Netherlands from 2010 to 2016.

question5b.value: The dataset was created by the university from its student information and enrollment systems to enable researchers of VU Amsterdam to conduct research based on validated, uniform, and anonymized student data.

question6b.value:
a.	The sample of 24,955 first-year, full-time students is the student population of 54 bachelor programs from 2010 to 2016 without students with other disabilities then autism (OD).
b.	For the Structural Equation Model the sample size is set to a minimum of 220 subjects: 10 subjects for each parameter (Kline, 2011).

question7b.value: As this dataset is the population of first-year, full-time students in 54 bachelor programs from 2010 to 2016 without OD, there is no data collection termination rule.

question9b.value: In this study, we will apply propensity score weighting (McCaffrey et al., 2013) to compare students with ASD to ND. If a balance between ASD and ND is not reached, the study will be stopped.

question7c.value: o	Missing data will be imputed, using the mice package (Van Buuren & Groothuis-Oudshoorn, 2011) and VIM package (Kowarik & Templ, 2016). Several methods will be explored to choose the optimal imputation: mean, median, KNN, and multiple imputations (Puma, Olsen, Bell, & Price, 2009; Rubin, 1987). For each imputed measure an additional measure will be added, indicating if the measure was imputed.

question8c.value: o	Different combinations of covariates will be tested to determine the subset of covariates that will give the best balance, using the cobalt package (Greifer, 2019).

question10c.value: o	We will use a correlation matrix before propensity matching to remove highly correlated covariates.

question1a.value:
In comparison to students with no disabilities (ND), we expect students with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) to have:
a.	H1 – a similar GPA 
b.	H2 – a lower exam participation 
c.	H3 – to accumulate significantly fewer credits 
d.	H4 – to need more time to complete a graduation assignment 
e.	H5 – to have the same retention rate 
f.	H6 – to have a lower degree completion rate

question5a.value:
a.	We want to test exam participation, GPA, credit accumulation, dropout rates, graduation assignment completion, and degree completion because many studies report lower graduation rates and higher dropout rates, but these studies have several limitations: 
i.	Studies based on evidence from higher education are limited and fragmented (Cox et al., 2017; Schindler, Cajiga, Aaronson, & Salas, 2015; Wei et al., 2016; White et al., 2016). 
ii.	Comparisons of students with ASD with neurotypical students are scarce. It is uncertain to what extent reported difficulties are unique to students with ASD. 
iii.	Reports on dropout and degree completion are collected from mostly qualitative studies with a limited number of students with ASD (Anderson, Stephenson, & Carter, 2017), and are not based analysis of the actual and entire student administration.
iv.	Insights in intermediate results (GPA, credit accumulation) are self-reported or absent. Therefore, it is unclear at what moment during their studies students with ASD face these problems, and if reported problems should be attributed to problems with the academic level of courses (GPA), the number of courses (lower credit accumulation) or both.
b.	We expect students with ASD to have a similar GPA, to study at a slower pace, and to have a similar retention rate (Bakker et al., 2020). Same data first year
c.	Frameworks regarding enrollment and transition of students with ASD are complementary, as they differ in dependent outcomes. Transition frameworks, such as the Taxonomy for Transition Programming (Taxonomy; Kohler, 1993; Wei, 2016; Haber et al., 2016; Trainor, Morningstar and Murray, 2016), take formal data on transition planning into account with enrollment as the dependent outcome. Student retention frameworks on the other hand, such as Input-throughput-output frameworks (Van Rooij et al., 2018, derived from Tinto, 1993 and Braxton, Milem and Sullivan, 2000; Astin, 1991; Van Rooij et al., 2018), have student success as the dependent outcome.

question1c.value:
o	Research Group: see 10a
o	H1: GPA in seven terms of each bachelor year (final GPA, failed final result)
o	H2: Exam participation in seven terms of each bachelor year (resits, no shows)
o	H3: Accumulated credits in seven terms of each bachelor year
o	H4: Graduation assignment: started (yes/no), completed (yes/no), days between start and completion of graduation assignment
o	H5: Retention rates after each bachelor year
o	H6: Degree completion rates after the third bachelor year; days between first enrollment and degree completion date 
o	Sex

o	Average Grade Secondary Education
o	Average Grade Dutch Secondary Education
o	Average Grade English Secondary Education
o	Average Grade Math Secondary Education

question2c.value:
o	R for statistical computing (R Core Team, 2017) will be used for data wrangling and data analysis.
o	Because of the expected differences in group sizes between ASD, OD, and ND, we will analyze the outcomes using propensity score weighting (PSW; McCaffrey et al., 2013).
o	To establish equal distributions, we will apply weighted Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to all continuous outcome measures.
o	We will apply weighted Complex Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) to analyze structural relationships using the lavaan.survey package (Oberski, 2014).
o	To test H1 (similar GPA) and H5 (similar retention rate) we will apply weighted Bayesian inference using the survey package (Lumley, 2004).

question3c.value:
o	IV: Research Group
o	DV H1: GPA for each term for each year
o	DV H2: Exam participation for each term for each year
o	DV H3: Accumulated Credits for each term for each year
o	DV H4: Graduation assignment started, Graduation assignment completed, Days between start and completion of graduation assignment
o	DV H5: Retention rate after each bachelor year
o	DV H6: Degree completion rates after the third bachelor year; days between first enrollment and degree completion date
o	Covariates for H1:H6:
	Sex
	Age at October 1
	Cohort
	Highest Pre-education
	Days between application and enrollment
	Average Grade Secondary Education
	Average Grade Dutch Secondary Education
	Average Grade English Secondary Education
	Average Grade Math Secondary Education

question4c.value:
o	We will add Sex, Cohort, and Highest Pre-education as possible confounders in the propensity matching to the treatment assignment (Kelcey, 2011; Bakker et al., 2020).
o	We will add Average Grade Math Secondary Education as outcome proxies to increase the power to test the treatment effect (Kelcey, 2011; Bakker et al., 2020).

question5c.value:
o	For GPA and Retention, we will:
1.	Calculate the likelihood distribution 
2.	Calculate the prior distribution based on GPA and retention of the total, unweighted population 
3.	Determine the posterior given the data
4.	Apply Bayesian hypothesis testing

question1c.value: Since all hypotheses are tested in the same way, see the information in the First Prediction.

registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a:
a.	We want to test exam participation, GPA, credit accumulation, dropout rates, graduation assignment completion, and degree completion because many studies report lower graduation rates and higher dropout rates, but these studies have several limitations: 
i.	Studies based on evidence from higher education are limited and fragmented (Cox et al., 2017; Schindler, Cajiga, Aaronson, & Salas, 2015; Wei et al., 2016; White et al., 2016). 
ii.	Comparisons of students with ASD with neurotypical students are scarce. It is uncertain to what extent reported difficulties are unique to students with ASD. 
iii.	Reports on dropout and degree completion are collected from mostly qualitative studies with a limited number of students with ASD (Anderson, Stephenson, & Carter, 2017), and are not based analysis of the actual and entire student administration.
iv.	Insights in intermediate results (GPA, credit accumulation) are self-reported or absent. Therefore, it is unclear at what moment during their studies students with ASD face these problems, and if reported problems should be attributed to problems with the academic level of courses (GPA), the number of courses (lower credit accumulation) or both.
b.	We expect students with ASD to have a similar GPA, to study at a slower pace, and to have a similar retention rate (Bakker et al., 2020). Same data first year
c.	Frameworks regarding enrollment and transition of students with ASD are complementary, as they differ in dependent outcomes. Transition frameworks, such as the Taxonomy for Transition Programming (Taxonomy; Kohler, 1993; Wei, 2016; Haber et al., 2016; Trainor, Morningstar and Murray, 2016), take formal data on transition planning into account with enrollment as the dependent outcome. Student retention frameworks on the other hand, such as Input-throughput-output frameworks (Van Rooij et al., 2018, derived from Tinto, 1993 and Braxton, Milem and Sullivan, 2000; Astin, 1991; Van Rooij et al., 2018), have student success as the dependent outcome.

Several methods will be explored to choose the optimal imputation: mean, median, KNN, and multiple imputations (Puma, Olsen, Bell, & Price, 2009; Rubin, 1987). For each imputed measure an additional measure will be added, indicating if the measure was imputed.

registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
o	Research Group: see 10a
o	H1: GPA in seven terms of each bachelor year (final GPA, failed final result)
o	H2: Exam participation in seven terms of each bachelor year (resits, no shows)
o	H3: Accumulated credits in seven terms of each bachelor year
o	H4: Graduation assignment: started (yes/no), completed (yes/no), days between start and completion of graduation assignment
o	H5: Retention rates after each bachelor year
o	H6: Degree completion rates after the third bachelor year; days between first enrollment and degree completion date 
o	Sex
o	Age at October 1
o	Cohort
o	Highest Pre-education
o	Average Grade Secondary Education
o	Average Grade Dutch Secondary Education
o	Average Grade English Secondary Education
o	Average Grade Math Secondary Education

o	R for statistical computing (R Core Team, 2017) will be used for data wrangling and data analysis.
o	Because of the expected differences in group sizes between ASD, OD, and ND, we will analyze the outcomes using propensity score weighting (PSW; McCaffrey et al., 2013).
o	To establish equal distributions, we will apply weighted Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to all continuous outcome measures.
o	We will apply weighted Complex Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) to analyze structural relationships using the lavaan.survey package (Oberski, 2014).
o	To test H1 (similar GPA) and H5 (similar retention rate) we will apply weighted Bayesian inference using the survey package (Lumley, 2004).

o	IV: Research Group
o	DV H1: GPA for each term for each year
o	DV H2: Exam participation for each term for each year
o	DV H3: Accumulated Credits for each term for each year
o	DV H4: Graduation assignment started, Graduation assignment completed, Days between start and completion of graduation assignment
o	DV H5: Retention rate after each bachelor year
o	DV H6: Degree completion rates after the third bachelor year; days between first enrollment and degree completion date
o	Covariates for H1:H6:
	Sex
	Age at October 1
	Cohort
	Highest Pre-education
	Days between application and enrollment
	Average Grade Secondary Education
	Average Grade Dutch Secondary Education
	Average Grade English Secondary Education
	Average Grade Math Secondary Education

o	We will add Sex, Cohort, and Highest Pre-education as possible confounders in the propensity matching to the treatment assignment (Kelcey, 2011; Bakker et al., 2020).
o	We will add Average Grade Math Secondary Education as outcome proxies to increase the power to test the treatment effect (Kelcey, 2011; Bakker et al., 2020).

o	For GPA and Retention, we will:
1.	Calculate the likelihood distribution 
2.	Calculate the prior distribution based on GPA and retention of the total, unweighted population 
3.	Determine the posterior given the data
4.	Apply Bayesian hypothesis testing
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: A large sample of 24,955 first-year, full-time students in 54 bachelor programs of a major university in the Netherlands from 2010 to 2016.

The dataset was created by the university from its student information and enrollment systems to enable researchers of VU Amsterdam to conduct research based on validated, uniform, and anonymized student data.

a.	The sample of 24,955 first-year, full-time students is the student population of 54 bachelor programs from 2010 to 2016 without students with other disabilities then autism (OD).
b.	For the Structural Equation Model the sample size is set to a minimum of 220 subjects: 10 subjects for each parameter (Kline, 2011).
As this dataset is the population of first-year, full-time students in 54 bachelor programs from 2010 to 2016 without OD, there is no data collection termination rule.

attributes.title: Task-induced Achievement Emotions and their Role in Visual Working Memory Performance: A Registered Report
attributes.description: Previous research has demonstrated that emotional states or emotional stimuli can influence visual working memory (VWM) performance. However, up to date there is a striking lack of research on whether the VWM task itself induces emotional experiences, and whether they impact VWM performance. In our registered report we argue that the VWM task can be considered an achievement situation, therefore leading to participants naturally experiencing achievement emotions (AE) including joy, pride, anger, and shame. Specifically, we hypothesize (1) that these AE correlate with individual differences in VWM performance, that this link is (2) mediated by subjective task performance (STP; i.e. how well or poorly participants think they are doing) and (3) moderated by performance goal orientation (PGO). Further, we believe (4) that AE, PGO, and task difficulty interact in predicting VWM. N = 225 participants will be recruited to perform the continuous colour wheel task. The task shall be comprised of 240 trials, which include arrays of either four (easy) or eight (difficult) coloured squares. Participants’ AE and STP will be obtained by self-report after the VWM task. We expect that our findings will highlight the relevance of AE as a potentially confounding variable for interpreting an individual’s VWM ability.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Task-induced Achievement Emotions and their Role in Visual Working Memory Performance: A Registered Report

sample.value: G*Power suggests a total sample size of n = 204. We aim to recruit 225 participants (approx. 10% more than estimated) in order to compensate any dropouts due to participants not finishing the study or due to data exclusion.

analyses.value:
To test H1, Pearson’s correlation coefficient will be obtained.
To test whether subjective task performance mediates (H2) and whether performance goal orientation moderates (H3) the relationship between achievement emotions and VWM performance, Hayes’ PROCESS macro for SPSS will be used (Hayes, 2012). 
Finally, to test whether task difficulty, emotions, and performance goal orientation interact in predicting VWM performance (H4), repeated-measures analysis of variance with covariates (ANCOVA) will be executed, with array-size as the repeated-measures factor, and performance goal orientation and the discrete emotions as covariates.  Specifically, we will test two sets of three-way interactions, namely (1) between task difficulty [four vs. eight], enjoyment (and pride, respectively [low, medium, high]) as well as performance approach orientation [low, medium, high], and (2) between task difficulty [four vs. eight], anger (and shame, respectively [low, medium, high]), and performance avoidance orientation [low, medium, high].

outliers.value:
Before data analysis, participants’ data will be scanned for substantial missing data in either the paper-pencil questionnaire or the visual working memory task (e.g. due to technical difficulties, such as data not being recorded accordingly), and outliers in the visual memory performance data in terms of poor performance (mean performance plus two standard deviations). 
Further criteria for exclusion from the study are the participants age (participants will be mainly students between the ages of 18 and 35), colour-blindness and any form of visual impairment that cannot be corrected to normal vision. Finally, participants must be able to speak German or English fluently.

dependent.value:
Visual working memory performance is the key dependent variable and will be measured by adopting the continuous colour recall paradigm (Zhang & Luck, 2008). 
We will operationalize visual memory performance by computing the absolute angular distance (in degrees) between the probed item’s colour (on the colour wheel) and the response’s colour (henceforth: recall error) for each participant.

conditions.value:
Task difficulty will be manipulated by varying the array size shown in the trials in a within-subject design. 
There will be two conditions: (1) in the easy condition trials will display four coloured squares, and (2) in the difficult condition trials will display eight coloured squares.

hypothesis.value: We hypothesize (H1) that task-induced achievement emotions correlate with individual differences in visual working memory performance, that this link is (H2) mediated by subjective task performance (i.e. how well or poorly participants think they are doing) and (H3) moderated by performance goal orientation. Further, we believe (H4) that achievement emotions, performance goal orientation, and task difficulty interact in predicting VWM.

attributes.title: Deprescribing paracetamol in adults with pain: a scoping review
attributes.description: Our aims are to understand what is known from existing research about strategies to deprescribe paracetamol in adults with pain. As well as what is known from existing research about how effective these strategies have been for deprescribing paracetamol in adults with pain.

attributes.title: Temporal Distancing Covid19
attributes.description: COVID-19 is rapidly spreading across the globe, resulting in millions of infections and hundreds of thousands of deaths to date. Fear and anxiety are especially prevalent emotions during an epidemic like this, and can have long-lasting negative consequences on psychological health. It is critical to identify strategies to help people better cope with the current epidemic. The aim is to provide insights and strategies to combat fear and anxiety, and to improve people’s psychological well-being, both during current epidemic and in similar future situations. Research has shown that psychological distance--temporally distancing the self from stressful events--promotes adaptive coping, mitigate emotional distress and reactivity, and improves adaptive emotional control. By eliciting a distant future perspective, the current research aims to reduce negative affect (e.g., anxiety/fear), and facilitate coping with current COVID-19 epidemic, through the mechanism of impermanent focus (i.e. focusing on transitory aspects of the stressor). Eventually, we plan to mitigate negative psychological consequences through online interventions because a timely online intervention is most desirable when opportunities to deliver in-person interventions are limited by widespread quarantine measures. Moreover, it guarantees easy access to the masses and allow interventions to be disseminated at a low cost.

q2.value: We hypothesize that temporally distancing the self from stressful events will reduce negative affect (e.g., anxiety/fear), and facilitate adaptive coping with current COVID-19 epidemic, through the mechanism of impermanent focus (i.e. focusing on transitory aspects of the stressor).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Between subject design: randomly assign Ps into condition (temporal distancing intervention vs. control). We will examine the effect of the condition immediately, and explore its effect a week later.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two blocks (intervention block vs. control block) using Qualtrics randomization procedure.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through advertisements on Facebook pages and Queen's university subject pool. Participants will either be given 1.0 course credit for their psych courses or be paid $10 for completing the survey at both time points. 
We will also recruit participants from China online, although we do not have reason to expect cultural differences.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 400 participants. Taking attrition into account, we will attempt to recruit up to 500 participants.

q12.value: Under the assumption that power = .85, α = .05, effect size f = .15 (assuming a small effect size), an a priori power analysis using G*Power3.1 (Faul, et al., 2009) estimated that a minimum sample size of 402 is required to detect the difference between intervention and control conditions.

question.value: We manipulated the intervention versus control condition. Participants randomly assigned to the intervention condition will be asked to imagine their lives 10 years into the future, and write about what their lives would be like in their imagined futures (e.g., what they might be doing or how they might be spending their time) in as much detail as possible. Participants in the control condition will be asked to imagine and write about what their lives would be like one week into the future.

Participants' affect will be measured using an adapted WHO (ten) well-being index measure. They will indicate the extent to which they feel each of the 10 statements at the moment (e.g., "I feel downhearted and blue right now", "I feel calm and peaceful right now", etc.) on a 7-point scale (1 = not at all, 7 = very much). Additionally, participants state anxiety will also be assessed using the 20-item STAI (e.g., "I feel calm", "I feel tense", etc.) on a 4-point scale (1 = not at all, 4 = very much so).
Participants' subjective well-being and optimism will also be assessed using 5-item subjective well-being life scale (e.g., "I am satisfied with my life"on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree)), and 7-item state optimism measure (e.g., "Right now, I expect things to work out for the best" on a 5-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree), respectively. 
Participants' coping and resilience will be measured using 4-item Brief Resilience Coping Scale (e.g., "I believe I can grow in positive ways by dealing with difficult situations" on a 5-point scale (1 = does not describe me at all), 5  = describes me very well)), and a 6-item Brief Resilient scale (e.g., "I tend to bounce back quickly after hard times" on a 5-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree).
The proposed mechanism, participants' temporal distancing, will be measured using the 8-item temporal distancing questionnaire (e.g., "I focus on how my feelings about the event may change with time", "I think about how small the event is in the bigger picture of my life", etc.) on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree).
We will compute the mean of each of the above measures as an index of their affect, anxiety, well-being, optimism, coping, resilience, and temporal distancing.

We will run one-way ANOVAs (with intervention and control conditions as the IV) to analyze the effect of the intervention at time 1 (post-manipulation) and time 2 (one-week follow up), independently. Additionally, we will use process to analyze whether temporal distancing mediated the effect of our intervention on the various outcome measures.

q19.value: We will use the standard NHST (p < .05) criteria for determining if the ANOVAs suggest any significant difference between the two conditions. We will also be using bootstrapping to determine whether the mediation analysis is significant or not.

q20.value: Participants who did not complete the intervention will be excluded. For example, participants who wrote nothing, or wrote that they have no idea what would happen 10 years down the road will be excluded from the analysis.

q21.value: Participants who did not complete the intervention will be excluded.

registration_responses.q6.question: Between subject design: randomly assign Ps into condition (temporal distancing intervention vs. control). We will examine the effect of the condition immediately, and explore its effect a week later.
registration_responses.q10.question:
Participants will be recruited through advertisements on Facebook pages and Queen's university subject pool. Participants will either be given 1.0 course credit for their psych courses or be paid $10 for completing the survey at both time points. 
We will also recruit participants from China online, although we do not have reason to expect cultural differences.
registration_responses.q14.question: We manipulated the intervention versus control condition. Participants randomly assigned to the intervention condition will be asked to imagine their lives 10 years into the future, and write about what their lives would be like in their imagined futures (e.g., what they might be doing or how they might be spending their time) in as much detail as possible. Participants in the control condition will be asked to imagine and write about what their lives would be like one week into the future.
registration_responses.q15.question:
Participants' affect will be measured using an adapted WHO (ten) well-being index measure. They will indicate the extent to which they feel each of the 10 statements at the moment (e.g., "I feel downhearted and blue right now", "I feel calm and peaceful right now", etc.) on a 7-point scale (1 = not at all, 7 = very much). Additionally, participants state anxiety will also be assessed using the 20-item STAI (e.g., "I feel calm", "I feel tense", etc.) on a 4-point scale (1 = not at all, 4 = very much so).
Participants' subjective well-being and optimism will also be assessed using 5-item subjective well-being life scale (e.g., "I am satisfied with my life"on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree)), and 7-item state optimism measure (e.g., "Right now, I expect things to work out for the best" on a 5-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree), respectively. 
Participants' coping and resilience will be measured using 4-item Brief Resilience Coping Scale (e.g., "I believe I can grow in positive ways by dealing with difficult situations" on a 5-point scale (1 = does not describe me at all), 5  = describes me very well)), and a 6-item Brief Resilient scale (e.g., "I tend to bounce back quickly after hard times" on a 5-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree).
The proposed mechanism, participants' temporal distancing, will be measured using the 8-item temporal distancing questionnaire (e.g., "I focus on how my feelings about the event may change with time", "I think about how small the event is in the bigger picture of my life", etc.) on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree).
registration_responses.q16.question: We will compute the mean of each of the above measures as an index of their affect, anxiety, well-being, optimism, coping, resilience, and temporal distancing.
registration_responses.q17.question: We will run one-way ANOVAs (with intervention and control conditions as the IV) to analyze the effect of the intervention at time 1 (post-manipulation) and time 2 (one-week follow up), independently. Additionally, we will use process to analyze whether temporal distancing mediated the effect of our intervention on the various outcome measures.

attributes.title: A survey experiment on healthcare chauvinism during the COVID-19 outbreak
attributes.description: This project tests for the occurence of healthcare chauvinism in Denmark amid the coronavirus outbreak.  To test this, we carry out a survey experiment with 12 experimental conditions conducted through the YouGov online panel. We apply a vignette-design (36 different combinations) to manipulate information about a fictitious COVID-19 patient. The main outcome is the degree to which the patient deserves treatment as a function of whether he has a Danish-sounding or a Muslim-sounding name.  We also vary two other factors: age (2 levels) and how long the patient has lived in Denmark (2 levels).

q2.value:
Main effects
1. Cues about a COVID-19 patient with a Muslim-sounding name increase negative attitudes of right to treatment.
2. Cues about an older COVID-19 patient increase negative attitudes of right to treatment.
3. Cues about a COVID-19 patient that recently migrated to Denmark increase negative attitudes of right to treatment.

2-way interaction effects
4. Cues about an older patient with a Muslim-sounding name increase negative attitudes of right to treatment.
5. Cues about a COVID-19 patient with a Muslim-sounding name that recently migrated to Denmark increase negative attitudes of right to treatment
6. Cues about an older patient that recently migrated to Denmark increase negative attitudes of right to treatment.

3-way interaction effect
7. Cues about an older patient with a Muslim-sounding name that recently migrated to Denmark increase negative attitudes of right to treatment.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
A between subjects design with 3 factors: Name, age, and length of residence. Name which is a proxy for ethnicity has 3 levels (popular Danish-sounding name, low status Danish-sounding name, and muslim-sounding name). Age has 2 levels (59 years old and 83 years old). Length of residence has 2 levels (lived in Denmark all his life and lived in Denmark one year). 

To test if socio-economic status confounds the relationship between name and deserving treatment, Danish name is split into two levels and assigned from two name pools with three names each. This is described in more detail in the pre-analysis plan.

q7.value: Subjects are randomly assigned to one of twelve experimental conditions. Conditions that include the muslim-name treatment are sampled twice the Danish-name treatments.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The data collection is administered by YouGov and conducted through their online panel. This includes sample selection and meeting the respondent quotas. The target group is Danish citizens aged 18 years or more. To secure a representative sample, data collection is based on quotas according to a target distribution on educational attainment (low, medium, and high), gender, age groups (18-29, 30-39, 40-49, 50-59 and 60+), and the five Danish regions. Respondents are incentivized to participate by receiving points for completion of the survey, which can be converted into gift cards through the YouGov panel store. Respondents are made aware of this when they begin the survey, including stipulations such as the full completion of the survey and reading the descriptions. 

Each respondent is assigned to one of 12 experimental conditions. The muslim-name conditions are sampled twice the Danish-name conditions. For a more detailed explanation see the pre-analysis plan.

q11.value: The minimum required sample size is 966 based on a power-analysis for detection of main effects. The target sample size is 1200 to increase the power of the study.

q12.value: The power study was conducted with the software program G*power, with the purpose of detecting a small main effect. We have an 80 % chance of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis of no differences with a total sample size of 966. The results are cross validated using the easy-power package in R.

question.value: 3 factors are manipulated. Name, age, and length of residence. Name which is a proxy for ethnicity has 3 levels (popular Danish-sounding name, low status Danish-sounding name, and muslim-sounding name). Age has 2 levels (59 years old and 83 years old). Length of residence has 2 levels (lived in Denmark all his life and lived in Denmark one year). Details of the name-treatment are found in the pre-analysis plan attached to the registration.

The below questions are measured on an 8-point likert scale. 
Q1: How concerned are you about a lack of resources at the hospitals (e.g. lack of hospital beds and/or medical staff)?
Q2: Based on the above scenario, to what degree do you feel this person should be prioritized a hospital bed?
Q3: In several German constituent states, they offer hospital beds for intensive care to COVID-19 patients from bordering French regions. To what degree do you feel that Denmark should open its borders for patients from neighboring countries?

The treatments are measured according to the levels described in the pre-analysis plan. 

I get access to the following pre-treatment covariates: Level of formal education, age (10-year intervals), gender, political viewpoint, party choice at last General election, Occupation, yearly income before taxes and a timestamp (DDMMYYYY) of the response.

All models are estimated with OLS multivariate regression. In model 1, we specify the three main effects adding covariates in model 2. After we conduct a series of models, one for each interaction effect. for each of these models, we include all the factors involved in the interaction as conditional effects. This process is repeated adding covariates. 
Further, we conduct sub-group analyses on relevant pre-treatment covariates and see if concern over hospital capacity moderates the relationship between name (ethnicity) and deserving treatment.

For model notation and a more comprehensive walkthrough, please see the attached pre-analysis plan.

q18.value: Treatment factors are dummy-coded. The reference-category for the name-treatment is popular Danish-sounding name. The reference category for the age-treatment is 59. The reference category for the length of residence-treatment is "lived in Denmark all his life".

q19.value: We use the p<.05 criteria for determining if the OLS-estimates suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q20.value: We will verify that each subject answered all three questions.

q21.value: If the subject does not answer all three questions presented in the survey or if the subject lacks information on the pre-treatment covariates, that subject will be excluded from the analysis.

q22.value: We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to the deservingness-outcome. Therefore, we examine relationships between the covariates and the primary outcome measure of deservingness.

q23.value: For a more detailed description of the information provided here, please see the pre-analysis plan attached to this pre-registration.

attributes.title: Impact on policy support of communicating evidence of the effectiveness of policies at achieving one or more benefits: an online experiment
attributes.description: Series of online studies (pre-pilot, pilot and main study) assessing the impact of communicating evidence of the effectiveness of goverment policies for achieving one or more benefits relating to reduced consumption of energy-dense food, meat and alcohol. The aim of the pilot studies is on developing the messages to be used in the main study

summary.value:
Background 
Excess consumption of energy-dense foods, meat and alcohol undermine both population and planetary health. Interventions that target contextual cues can reduce consumption of these products. Public support of such interventions - key to their implementation - is lower than support for providing persuasive information, a less effective intervention. Communicating evidence of an intervention’s effectiveness at achieving a policy goal increases public support. 

Aims
We are planning a study to assess the potential additional impact of communicating evidence of policies at achieving one or more benefits resulting from attaining a given policy goal. The study will focus on two sets of policies to reduce consumption - introducing taxes and altering the availability of products - targeting three products that harm health – energy-dense food, meat and alcohol –  presented as effective at achieving one compared to three benefits, relating to population health, healthcare costs and planetary health. The primary hypothesis to be tested is that support for a policy increases as the number of benefits presented increases.

There is uncertainty, however, about how to describe each benefit to optimise the influence of effectiveness information on policy support. Therefore, prior to conducting the aforementioned study, we will conduct a series of two pilot studies, to assess the impact of using messages with different levels of details (i.e. explanations for how the target behaviour causes adverse outcomes that do and do not include an additional statement that changing the target behaviour has benefits i.e. reverses the adverse outcomes; explanations that include or avoid wording that can be interpreted as attributing individual responsibility for the target behaviours; for messages referring to planetary health, explanations that do and do not include a statement linking carbon emissions to planetary health) (Pilot Study 1) and of different length (i.e. short simple messages or longer messages that make explicit the causal link between the target behaviour and the benefits) (Pilot Study 2).

Method
Main study:
Online study using a 4 (Evidence of effectiveness communication: no message; assertion of effectiveness for changing target behaviour; assertion of effectiveness for changing behaviour and achieving one benefit; assertion of effectiveness for changing behaviour and achieving three benefits) x 3 (Behaviour: consumption of energy-dense food; alcohol; meat) x 2 (policy: taxation; reducing product availability) between-subjects factorial design, in which 3768 participants will be randomised to one of 24 groups. The primary outcome is support for the policy. The messages used in the study will be developed following pilot and pre-pilot work.

Pilot Study 1:
Online study using a mixed within)/between-subjects design. 

Within-subjects factor: 
Benefits -  3 levels: 
•	reduced cancer rates
•	reduced healthcare costs
•	reduced carbon emissions

Between-subjects factor:
Message type- – 4/7* levels: 
•	message that does not include additional statement about the reversal of adverse outcomes
•	message that includes additional statement about reversal of adverse outcomes
•	message that attributes individual responsibility for behaviour
•	message that does not attribute individual responsibility for behaviour

*three additional levels for benefits relating to planetary health: 
•	message that includes mention of carbon emissions only
•	message that includes mention of environmental harms
•	message that includes an explicit explanation of the link between carbon emissions and environmental harms

252 participants will view information relating to one behaviour (consumption of energy-dense snacks) and one policy (taxation). Each participant will be asked to read and rate three messages, one relating to each policy benefit (cutting cancer rates, cutting healthcare costs; cutting carbon emissions). The message type will be determined by randomisation.
Messages will be rated for their believability (primary outcome) and perceived coherence.  After completing the ratings, participants will be asked to indicate their understanding of carbon emissions and environmental harms (through use of a free text box) and to rate the importance of cutting each.

Pilot Study 2:

Online study using a mixed within)/between-subjects design:

Between-subjects factor: 
1.	Wording of messages -  2 levels: 
•	Short
•	Detailed

2.	Benefits - 4 levels
•	Reduced cancer rates
•	Reduced healthcare costs
•	Reduced carbon emissions
•	All three combined

Within-subjects factor: 
1.	Behaviour - 3 levels: 
•	Consumption of energy-dense snacks
•	Consumption of meat	
•	Consumption of alcohol

1000 participants will each read and rate three separate messages, one relating to each target behaviour. The content of the messages (short vs detailed; describing benefits relating to cancer rates vs healthcare costs vs carbon emissions) and the order in which they are presented will be determined by randomisation. The primary outcome will be perceived policy effectiveness.
